gt_metadata.note: Freeform Stacking: Leah reviews entire document including CP redlines. CP redlines are adversarial (proposed by Processor, weaken Controller position). Leah should REJECT or MODIFY.

part_a_cp_redlines.original_text: Controller hereby provides general written authorisation for Processor to engage Sub-processors. Processor shall notify Controller of any intended changes to Sub-processors at least thirty (30) days prior to such changes. Controller may object to such changes by providing written notice to Processor within the notice period.
part_a_cp_redlines.cp_redline: Controller hereby provides general written authorisation for Processor to engage Sub-processors for the Processing of Personal Data. Processor shall maintain an up-to-date list of Sub-processors available upon Controller's request.
part_a_cp_redlines.cp_effect: Removes 30-day advance notice requirement; removes Controller objection right; reduces to passive list maintenance only
part_a_cp_redlines.example_revision: Controller hereby provides general written authorisation for Processor to engage Sub-processors. Processor shall notify Controller of any intended changes to Sub-processors at least thirty (30) days prior to such changes. Controller may object to such changes by providing written notice to Processor within the notice period.
key_elements: 1) Advance notice of sub-processor changes (minimum 14 days, prefer 30)
3) Consequence for objection (termination right or Processor must not proceed)
acceptable_variations: Notice period reduced to 14-21 days acceptable
Deemed consent if no objection within notice period
Pre-approved sub-processor list with consent required for others
part_a_cp_redlines.reasoning_must_address: GDPR Art 28(2) requires Controller authorisation; advance notice enables due diligence; objection right is fundamental Controller protection; passive list is inadequate

part_a_cp_redlines.original_text: Processor shall notify Controller of any Personal Data Breach without undue delay and in any event within seventy-two (72) hours of becoming aware of such breach.
part_a_cp_redlines.cp_redline: Processor shall notify Controller of any Personal Data Breach without undue delay and in any event within five (5) business days of confirming such breach. Notification shall be limited to information Processor determines is necessary.
part_a_cp_redlines.cp_effect: Extends notification from 72 hours to 5 business days (potentially 7+ calendar days); changes trigger from 'becoming aware' to 'confirming' (allows delay); limits information to Processor's discretion
part_a_cp_redlines.example_revision: Processor shall notify Controller of any Personal Data Breach without undue delay and in any event within seventy-two (72) hours of becoming aware of such breach.
key_elements: 3) Information provided must enable Controller assessment
acceptable_variations: Initial notice within 24-48 hours, full details within 72 hours
Specified information requirements (nature, scope, affected data subjects, remediation)
unacceptable_responses: Accepting Processor discretion over information provided
Any timeline exceeding 72 hours without justification
part_a_cp_redlines.reasoning_must_address: Controller has 72-hour regulatory notification obligation under GDPR Art 33; 'becoming aware' is the legal standard; Controller needs information to assess regulatory obligations and data subject notification requirements

part_a_cp_redlines.original_text: Processor shall indemnify Controller against any claims, damages, or regulatory fines arising from Processor's breach of this DPA or Data Protection Laws.
part_a_cp_redlines.cp_redline: Processor shall indemnify Controller against direct damages arising from Processor's gross negligence or wilful misconduct in breach of this DPA, excluding any regulatory fines, penalties, or administrative sanctions.
part_a_cp_redlines.cp_effect: Narrows trigger from 'breach' to 'gross negligence or wilful misconduct' (very high bar); excludes regulatory fines entirely; limits to direct damages only
part_a_cp_redlines.example_revision: Processor shall indemnify Controller against any claims, damages, or regulatory fines arising from Processor's breach of this DPA or Data Protection Laws.
key_elements: 1) Indemnification triggered by breach (not just gross negligence)
2) Regulatory fines included (or capped, not excluded)
3) Not limited to direct damages only
acceptable_variations: Proportionate fault allocation where both parties contributed
Processor participation rights in regulatory proceedings
Exclude fines for Controller-caused violations only
unacceptable_responses: Accepting complete exclusion of regulatory fines
part_a_cp_redlines.reasoning_must_address: GDPR fines can reach â‚¬20M or 4% global turnover; Processor breach creates Controller regulatory exposure; gross negligence standard effectively eliminates indemnification; Controller cannot absorb Processor-caused fines

part_a_cp_redlines.original_text: Audits shall be conducted with reasonable notice during normal business hours, no more than once per year, and at Controller's expense.
part_a_cp_redlines.cp_redline: Audits shall be conducted with no less than sixty (60) days' prior written notice during normal business hours, no more than once every two (2) years, and at Controller's sole expense. Controller shall provide Processor with the audit scope and methodology for approval prior to any audit. Processor may satisfy audit requirements by providing a SOC 2 Type II report in lieu of on-site audit.
part_a_cp_redlines.cp_effect: Extends notice from 'reasonable' to 60 days minimum; reduces frequency from annual to biennial; requires Processor approval of audit scope (defeats independence); allows SOC 2 substitution (removes direct audit right)
part_a_cp_redlines.example_revision: Audits shall be conducted with reasonable notice (not less than fourteen (14) business days) during normal business hours, no more than once per year, and at Controller's expense. Processor shall provide Controller with SOC 2 Type II reports annually; such reports shall supplement but not replace Controller's direct audit rights.
key_elements: 3) Controller determines audit scope (not subject to Processor approval)
4) SOC 2 supplements but does not replace direct audit right
acceptable_variations: SOC 2 accepted for routine compliance, with direct audit right for cause
Additional audit permitted following breach or complaint
Processor bears costs if material deficiencies found
unacceptable_responses: Accepting Processor approval of audit scope
Accepting SOC 2 as complete substitute for direct audit
part_a_cp_redlines.reasoning_must_address: GDPR Art 28(3)(h) requires Controller audit rights; 60 days notice undermines audit effectiveness; Processor scope approval defeats audit independence; SOC 2 is point-in-time and may not cover Controller-specific concerns

part_b_whole_document.degradation_note: All 12 baseline issues remain detectable. CP redlines worsen 4 existing issues but do not resolve any. Leah should detect all baseline issues AND respond appropriately to CP redlines.

critical_failures: ACCEPT on any CP redline (all are adversarial)
Revision fails to restore Controller protections
